stem: A patient has clawing of digits 4 and 5 with loss of finger abduction and sensation over the medial dorsal hand after an injury proximal to the wrist. Which clinical finding helps distinguish this proximal lesion from a pure Guyon canal entrapment?

choices.A: Loss of dorsal ulnar hand sensation
choices.B: Weakness of lumbricals to digits 4 and 5
choices.D: Atrophy of the first dorsal interosseous muscle

rationale_correct: Proximal ulnar lesions (before the dorsal cutaneous branch) reduce dorsal ulnar hand sensation, whereas Guyon canal compression spares dorsal sensation.

rationale_distractors.B: Both proximal and distal lesions weaken the lumbricals to digits 4 and 5.
rationale_distractors.C: Froment sign appears with both proximal and distal motor involvement.
rationale_distractors.D: Interosseous atrophy occurs in both locations.
rationale_distractors.E: Hypothenar wasting can occur with either lesion affecting the deep motor branch.
